div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,413] ALEXANDRIA, Wednesday, FEBRUARY 7, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Office of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, Every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindiel Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined sea and special train fare os 22.9.11 Port said to london via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent. on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London calling Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every altenate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: CYPRUS AND ITS SHIPPING INTERESTS.
div.p: In a note about Cyprus in a recent issue of the "Gazette" it was stated that shipowning has had so far only an inferior share of the commerce of the Island. Large, indeed, as is the field yet for the development of the British shipping trade in Cyprus it should not be denied that British owners have so far had the lion's share, especially in the exportation department of Cyprian trade. The Westcott and Laurance Line and the Prince Line, Ltd, have for some time now been running a more or less regular service to Cyprus, but the credit is in a great measure due to the enterprise of the latter company. Indeed the Prince

Line steamers have for the last decade been serving the Island with fair frequency and despite conditions of the most ungrateful and discouraging nature, have slowly but surely been contributing to the development of the Cyprian trade with the United Kingdom. The bulk of the material for the Famagusta harbour and railway and for the extension of the latter to Morfou, has been transported by the Prince Line steamers. The number of this company's ships that have called at Cyprus since January last year amounts to about 21, and had it not been for the diversion last year, to Egypt and the North African Coast, of a great part of the cereals, principally barley and wheat, that would have otherwise been destined to the United Kingdom, the tonnage supply would have been larger still.

Unfortunately the Government of Cyprus, busy perhaps with more pressing reforms, have not given the attention due to a British company that has laid itself out so generously and enterprisingly to aid in the development of the Island's agricultural and commercial resources. Quite recently, however, the Prince Line, through its general agent for Syria and Cyprus, has drawn the attention of the High Commissioner to certain disabilities under which its steamers were labouring. His Excellency has accorded a generous attention to the matter, and one of the first fruits of his efforts in this direction has been the abolition of the old Sunday fines that had not much raison d'etre, and their replacement by a rational system of overtime fees to be allowed to Customs officials, registrars, weighers, etc. His Excellency has, moreover, taken the initiative in another and far more important direction, viz, the suppression of certain out-of-the-way places not to be found on any chart of Cyprus for the simple reason that there are scarcely, if any, habitable, dwellings to mark the spots, and from which an appreciable part of the staple product of the Island, viz., locust beans, is shipped.

The locust bean crop of 1904 was estimated at as many as 40,000 tons, and at least half of this quantity has been exported to the United Kingdom. Now, as we have noted, a not inconsiderable part of this stuff is shipped from the above-mentioned outlandish places where there are none of the modern appliances for loading and not even small wooden jetties and frequent have been the disastrous detentions sustained by steamers attempting to load thereat. The Prince Line, in view of its preponderant supply of tonnage, has naturally home the largest share of the losses sustained through these abnormal detentions, and it naturally felt a legitimate feeling of satisfaction and pride in having been the pioneer for the introduction of reforms calculated to contribute so considerably to the advancement of British shipping interests. The loading of looust beans and indeed any other produce is to be confined to recognised ports where the loading conditions, whether natural or artificial,are more or less favourable.

But it seems that the Cyprian peasant, with his laziness and his inherent aversion to innovations even in the shape of beneficial reforms, has set himself against the application of the new measure, and has, strange as it may seem, got his way. One cannot but share the disappointment that must have been felt by the shipping companies concerned in the shipping trade ofCyprus and the majority of whom are British. But the largest share of sympathy is due to the Prince Line, whose generous and enterprising efforts have been so ill-requited, seeing that this company, to help in the development of Cyprian trade with the United Kingdom, has so far refrained from stipulating lay days in its engagements and obviated the onerous conditions of demurrage. At the worst, however, the Prince Line, with its fast growing trade in Syria and Palestine, may find it suitable to divert part of its tonnage, hitherto allotted to Cyprus, to this coast, where the loading conditions are manifestly superior, and the Island itself will then be the loser. It is to be hoped, however, that in the interest of the land whose

government has been entrusted to his wise management and judicious care his Excellency the High Commissioner will not heed the protests of an ignorant and shortsighted class of Cyprians, and vouchsafe a generous cooperation to shipping interests, for to an island, steamship communication is a factor of absolutely vital importance.

We have omitted to mention that in his plan of reforms, prompted by the representations of the Prinoe Line, his Excellency the High Commissioner has included the construction of wooden jetties at the principal small ports at which the operations of loading were to be authorized only. It will take probably some time for the accomplishment of this very important project but we are sure that once it has received the attention of the Governor it will eventually be realized.

It is sincerely to he hoped now that letters ard newspapers are to he delivered at the booses of the addresses without a special appli cation having to he made, and that the postal authorities will see that misdeliveries are le«* fiequent than heretofore. It is continually happening that letters are delivered to persons who happen to have the same name as the addressees in spite of the faot that the address is written with absolute legibility. Theie is considerable probability, it appears, that an agreement may he concluded between the Anglo-Egyptian and the Italian Governments, w th regard to the frontier of Tripoli.

The boundary line between Egypt and Tripoli is practically the only one in the African Con- - tinent now remaining to he settled. div.head: NEW SUDAN RAILWAY - THE VISIT TO KHARTOUM
div.p: Legislators and Pressmen was named in our programme for the Khartoum stay, coaid not have formed a very favourable impression of the capital of the Sudan from their first morning's view of Khartoum North and Tati Island. A strong wind was blowing olonds of dust and sand in all direotions, the son seemed uncom fortably hot, and the party who were alba the visitor by repeating various trite starzas. little tired after their railway journey found Those who prefer the 'Four Feathers to the heat trying. Breakfast over, all set ont to 'Fire and Sword in the Sudan' or take the the steam tram line, and for the rest of the desert cities of the Sahara visited by the nen- morning saw the principal sights ot Khartoum rotio hero and improbable heroine of the .'Gar- under the guidanoe of Col. 8tan ton that the sonlptor had taken an Indian camel for his model, and had given Gordon's 'hagim' a short mane or rather a group of tufts around the Deck which are never seen on the 8ndan beasts. The Palace and the Government Offices were contrasted. The white walls of the Palace look well enough and the gardens, which would ha admired anywhere, mast seem a paradise in the Sudan, hut as far as the actual building goes, arches and shady windows look more suited to the climate. With temperatures of from 90 % to 95 % Fahrenheit in the first week of February one could gness what the heat was like'y to he ait* r April. After the Palace and the statae we passed the British Barracks wheie the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment with a small R.G.A. heat and 'hahonhs,' save their money, and have the same officers that Alexandria knew.

The water works praotioally end the town. They are to be finished—Inahallah—in October next and will sapply all Khartoam with sweet water. At present the Nile famishes practically the whole supply and the Nile water at Khartoam is as good as it is anywhere. Still an epidemic is always a possibility in the tropios and the capital of the Sudan must run no risks. As long as the Arabian coast towns and Meoca itself are nests of disease, returning pilgrims may always bring the oholere with* them from the H»djaz, and on the long coast between Jebel Elba, and the southern frontier line near Massowah there are plenty of ohanoes of evading quarantine. The water works are to be complete'! at a cost of only £80,000 exclusive of tha cost of the pipes and of laying them down. There are five artesian wells sunk under the supervision of Sig. Bettali, who knows all that is to be known about artesian wells, while Mr. Pietsob, formerly one of Messrs. Cook's superintendents, looks after the engines. The pumps are of the 'Hayward-Tyler plunger' model of which there are three sets of three each. Water—sweet water that is—was tound at a depth of fifty metres all found above that, depth beiug relty or at least brackish. The water tower from which a nmarkably good vi w can be obtained—will bo shout IK) feet high. The great tank will contain 760 tons of water—a ooLfhterablo weight being nocea sary to drive the water along the pipes for » distance of at least 2j| miles. Filters will be provided and the iron wurk and machinery is thoroughly up to date.

On Tuesday, Feb 80, the party visited Om the men whom we saw in the streets were fioe well made fellows who walked with a long, springing stride and held their head np. The 'conquered' races did not seem to be the worse for the conquest as far as their manliness went and everything showed that their material instincts were being well looked after by a paternal Government.

Of coarse we saw the Beit el Amana, the Khalifa's house, the tomb of the Mahdi bearing the marks of the shells that stnok in it in the great fight, and—straDge contrast—the Higher Elementary school whew the little Dervishes, black and Arab, repeated passages from the Koran with an intonation that delighted the Legislative Councillors, and recited English with a fluency, that made of ns blush to remember oar own lame and impotent efforts when called upon to bore woie as gross as they were savage and whose | very religious fervoor expressed itself in. a frank detestation of all art and civilisation. Like the Dervish coins which were presented us, the uncoath rains ot carriages that we saw, everyone of the Khalifa's buildings gave the impression of barbarism tricked out in a few rags and tatters of civilisation.

Another ten years and the carriages, the rides, the steamers, all would have fallen to piece* or peribhed from negleot There was | nor hing in the remains of Derwisb rule to exoite more than a pitying ouriosity

div.head: PRESS AND SUDAN GOVERNMENT
div.p: Tne Press correspondents left Wadi Haifa on the evening of the 3rd inst. by the G.S. journey had a pleasant little epilogoe. After dinner M R. Canivet rose amid applause and in an eloquent and graoefcl speech thanked the Governor General of the Sadan and his subordinates for the kindness with which the Press representative had been treated. He desired in partionlar to thank Owen Bey for the kindness with which he had looked after the members of the Press during their trip and after referring to the Sudan and its marvellous developement remarked that Owen Bey had met with extraordinary suooess in poitying members of a most tarbolent class who were now eager to drink his health.

Tadros Bey Shenonda also proposed Owen Bey's health on behalf of the repr sentatives of the Native Press. He repeatedly referred to the kindness and hospitality of the Sudan Government and stated that he was happy to have had the opportunity of aooompaning his Europe colleagues to the Sudan. The progress made by the oonntry since his last visit delighted and amazed him and the Govemmen deserved the highest credit. In the Dame the Arabic Press he offered his sinoere thanks to the Sirdar and to Owen Bey.
The Sodan Agent responded to the toast of his health as follows

"Gentlemen. 1 most tell yon, I ha e come totally unprepared to make a speeoh and 1 fear I have not had muoh practice in speech making. I fear too that I cannot reply toM. Canivet or to Tadros Bey in Freooh or Arabio ; Mr. Dicey advises me to speak in Welsh bm I fear 1 have iftt spoken my native tongue for many years. But I can assure you very heartily that this trip has been of exceptional interest to me, the more so as I have not before had the privilege of meeting the repre sentatives of the Looal Press. I read tbeirpapers hut I did not happen to know the members of the Press personally. This was my mi fortune; now I have had the good fortune to have travelled with them, I can only hoio that the acquaintanceship, or rather friendship once begun may continue." After mm* oomi limentary references to the Press, Own B* y continued as follows: To torn to the Sudan, we British are often accused r f beinf grasping, the aocusation is untruo. You wP find us compelled by an inner force, a sense of duty, hard to oxpiain hero to do our bee for the country which you are now leaving and the people to whom it belongs. 1 may remark hore that some years ago all of us might have bought landed properties in the Sudan at P.T. 6 per feddan, and that suoh properties are now worth fifty times that amount By our not being allowed to buy land our hands are

I thank you once more in the name of H E. the Governor General for your snpport of ftnd,acqnie«oenoe in the rrrangements we have made and I shall leave yon feeling what a truly good lot of fellows you all are (Loud ApplanreV

After Naoum Bey Shnkair's health had been drnnk and Conut de Collalto had pro- deal of its representatives on the journey and had found them equal to thore of any Press m the world. When first he knew Egypt the Press was far below the level it reached in other ooantries. Even 10 years ago it left muoh to be desired. He himself had said that no journal in Egypt would ever have a circulation that would make it of real importance. He was now happy to acknowledge that he had been wrong and now wished all those present long advertisments and big oiroulati ns

Mr. Hafiz Awad replied for the Press in English as follows "It would be easier for me to speak in my own language and my slight knowledge of English must excuse any faults I make. I desire to express in the name of the Egyptian Press our gratitude to H. E. the Governor General of the Sudan. We have been much interested and impre-sed by our visit and overflowing as many lonobeon parties were in the honoor of having among us. I thank him for progress, and very many folk from Cairo bad the kind expressions he has used of the Bgyp- taken time by the forelook and bad jonrneyed tian Press, and 1 hope that we shall show that ont dnring the morning. div.head: MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS
div.p: Two letters have recently appeared in our oolumns on the subject cf the Alexandria Municipal elections, which have, it would appear, caused some stir. The writers ream to be under the impression that absolute disinterestedness in non existent in the Municipality and that self-seeking or vanity are the motives, which iuduce persons to come forward as candidates at the Municipal elections. We are therefore delighted to publish the following letter from the Vice President of the Municipality, which categorically oontradicts these assumptions. At the same time we might point oot that the members of the Municipalsy carefully exclude all attempts to admit the Press at their debates, and this may possibly have induced a certain seotion of the pohlio to D^"f^rm sone unfavourable opinions as to the oi motives for this decision, especially in view of the faot that a former Municipal Councillor dec ared the official reports of the debates to he 'cooked.'' Whether the authors of these litters deserve to be stigmatised with the severity which Mr. Balli employs maybe a matter of doubt, especially in view of the faot that in well informed o roles yesterday the anthor- bhip or inspiration of one or other of these communications were actually imputed to a Municipal Councillor.

div.head: PERSONAL AN SOCIAL
div.p: Don Carlos, Duke of Madrid, and the Dachess, who left Cairo for Jerusalem on Saturday last will return there on the l4th inst The Duke's aidede-oamp is General Don Rodrigo de Medina y Esquivel. Before his departnre the Doke presented Chakhonr Paoha with a maguifioent scarf pin, sannonnted by a crown and bearing his initials.
This Countess of Enniskillen is leaving Alexandria for Earope this afternoon on her return to Europe by the North German Lloyd's S.S. Schleswig
Sir William Garstin has been passing Konrban Beyram at Luxor.
The Adviser to the Ministry of Public Works had an interview with Lord Cromer on Monday.
Hon. A. Stanley, who nearly four years ago was attached to the British Agency at CairOi has arrived in the Capital.

The Hon. Francis Napier, Master of Napier, who is at present staying at the Gheareh Palace Hotel, is the eldest son and heir of the 11th Baron Napier and Ettriok and a descan dan t of that oelebrated John Napier, Laird of Merohiston, who devoted the later years of his life to literary and scientific study.

Lady Westmacott, who is staying aft the Hotel da Nil, is the wife of that gallant soldier and keen sportsman, Major-General Sftr Biobard Westmacott, K.C.B., D.8.O., who has seen mote active service than of his most contemporaries. Joining the Bombay army daring the year of the Indian mutiny his first experience of the East was gained daring those troublous months. In the following year he wss engaged in subduing the rebel Bbeels. and in 1863 he took an active part agairst the Naikras. He was in the Afghan war of 1879, and in 1886 was sent to take part in the Sudan Expedition.
Mr. Moherly Bell is staying at Ghezireh Palsoe Hotel

The following left Cairo last night by thti train de Inxe for Upper Egypt; Mr. and Mrs. Dodge, Mr. Melekers, Mr. and Mrs. Jea Cousins, Mr. and Mrs. H. Lewis, Miss Henry, Mist Coontz, Mr. Richetson, Mr. Kensbach, Mr. and Mme. Adi, Ahmed Eff. Cbafik, Mob. Bey Moustapha, Mme Frayeer, Mr. Anderson, Mr. Sinnot Hanna.
Mr. Edward Dicey, C.B., is at the 8evojr Hotel, Assouan.

Colonel Charles Evan Maberly, who is staying at the Savoy Hotel, is *0 stranger to this country, having distinguished himself in thg Nile campaign of 1884 and 1886, when he was severely wounded and for his bravery earned the Queen's medal with clasp and the D.8.O. He is the son of the late Major-General BvaA Maberly, C.B. of Avonmonth House, Christchurch, and his sister married Sir Edmond Tracy Hardinge.

It is a pleasing doty to congratulate Mr. Philip Beofee, Director of the Menshieh prisons, on his promotion to the rank of Bimbashi. Mr. Beufee has now been in Cairo for many years and his numerous friends will be glad to hear of hie well-deserved promotion.

div.head:
AUSTRIA AND HUNGARY
A PACIFIC TENDENCY.

div.p: The Hangarian ooalition has publi'hed manifesto enunciating their position towards the Crown, but, oontrary to anticipations, it has met with a mixed reception. A strong tendenoy is manifested in favour of paoifi aotion based on reciprocal concessions. (B.
It is noted that as a consequence of the negotiations between the Crown and Hungarian coalitions, there exists a pacifio tetidenoy, the basis of which is a policy of reciprocal con cessioc. (Havas)
The funeral of King Christian will take place on the 18th inst. (Reuter)

Enthusiastic feting and ovating of the London County Councillors is taking place. The inventorying of the ohurohes has been sus pended during their visit in order to avoid possible disorders. (Renter)
Disturbances between Catholics and Suoinl ists are reported. Many arrests have been made. (Home)
Two thousand more redifs with two mountain batteries have sailed for Yemen. (Beuter)

div.head: GYP AND ENGLAND
div.p: IMPRESSIONS OF A COUNTRY BY ONE WHO HA8 NEVER VISITED IT.

As everybody knows, " Gyp," novelist politician, aejiyely associated with the Bonlangist, Anti-Semitic, and Nationalist movements, has strong feelings against England, which she ha3 never visited. In an interview with a representative of the "Standard" these are expressed with amusing vigour.

" When one contrasts a woman who is a 8U00688 as a woman with the annexed female— well it serves England right that she possesses so many caricatures of femininity ! It is such a pity, too, for the women there are very beantifal, muoh more so than the Frenchwomen. Even when they dress in London they have a chic all their own, and the sympathet:o Englishwoman is fall of charm. The men ? Oh, they are beantifal—to look at. The aristocratic Englishman is snperb; no man dresses so well ; he is chivalrous ; his manners are absolutely correct. He would be perfeot if he never talked, but directly he opens his month I detest him. He is—mode !"

"But snrely the English have some virtues, I said, after a lively disoussion as to the exact meaning of "mufle." "Can't you pay a good word for anything but the beauty of the women? ' She reflected. "English people eat very nicely. I like to watch them at table just for the pleasure of seeing how graoefully they do iK Even the lower classes have something of the same elegance—always a clean cloth, always a change of knife and fork, and a neat way of disposing of their food. And they never rob the bread round and round the plate to sop op the saloe as other people do, as I do when I have sanoe Ilemonlade—with my fingers, mark, not with a fork. I admire their patriotism ; their love of oonntry is beantifal. As business people they are, of coarse, admirable ; they have a genius for finance, are generous in their payments, and honest Never so honest, however, as when they are very dishonest. One of the strong points of the English character is its elasticity of conscience. They strive not only to j astify—that is excas- able—bnt to olcthe with virtue their every aotion. Take the history of their wars, for example. How many have they had in which they have not posed as a moral as well as a material force ? It is always for the good of the other nation. The *entente cordiale V An excellent arrangement for the English, as those who made it will find out to their coat sooner or later. I prefer to believe it is not seripns enough to be discussed. Parlous dautre chose.'* A Strong Indictment.

But it was too late. Gyp is a red hot Nationalist, and sitting with her profile outlined against, and astonishingly like, that of the bust of Mirabeu juBt behind her, she spoke her mind. "It's the same self-righteousness that destroys their sense of jastice, and makes them anable to mete out an unprejudiced punishment. There have been one or two ocoaions when the whole of civilised Earope has tram bled with indignation at their actions. Think. They knew an evil existed, and that it ought to be eradicated, or at least subdued. Trfo bien. They concluded they must make au example of some one. Not fur, but still—not oriminal. Who was the victim to be ? There was a man of genins who had already done something to beautify life for them, a man -wlnse brilliant talents aid artistic temperament onght to have exonerated Am from ordinary roles, or at least have made him an objeot of sympathy and pity. That was the man they chose to make their publio example of, gloating over their chanoe, raking op all th\t belonged to hi* private life and himself, disgracing him in the eyes of all conventional persons, throwing him in prison, broken in spirit, wasting his genius, sending him to a pauper's grave—murderers ! And all England hugged itself and said, 'How virtuous we are !' Those who committed the same sin saying it the loudest. Hypocrites 1" Hypocrite*.

"Yes, hypocrites !" she cried, her eyes blazing.. "The English character is rooted in hypoorisy, and that is why I hats it. To hear them talk, and read their books, and see their pose yon would think them the pnreot and only pure nation in the world. Look below the sarface, and what do yon find ? Making allow ance for the dififerencs of temperament caused by racial and o'imatio influences the English are exactly the same morally as any other nation. In which o*her country is religion so often used as a oloak for every kind of breach of confidence ?

Not to be found out is the real religion of the English, and they demonstrate their belief in the efficacy of the ten commandments by crying shame on the unpardonable sinners who have broken this first law."

It was only when Gyp had vigorously poked the fire, had carried a very heavy log of wood across the room, had settled it energetically into place and poked and raked again, that she recovered her equanimity. Then she sat down, sighed, and finally smiled her vivid smile.
"Anyway, we're all human here," she said, getting op again to hand round some bon-bons "tat'a talk of things as they are, and be happy. Have o'e of the^e—th y are made specially for ite."

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE
div.p: The trade in confectionery in this conntry may be roughly divided into two classes viz : the very cheap goods for the Arabs, and the more expensive qualities for the Europeans. As regards the first and greatest division, England practioally has a monopoly, whilst h^r . rontribntion to the seoond category is almost nil, except in the case of two or three firms sending over plain ohocolates.

Althoagh the total turnover in oonfeotionery rons into fairly large figures, the trade is not important enough to warrant separate returns being kept for it at the Customs, and we aro, therefore, unable to quote statistics relating solely to the sweets imported into Egypt daring any period.

In regard to the 1904 retnrnp, we find that the quantities supplied by the various countries for every L.E. 1 received by them were as follows: — Turkey 42.8 kilograms, England 31.9, Italy 13.7, France 10.8 and Switzerland 12.

Outside Turkey with her comparatively small shipment, no country can compete with England in supplying this market with the low grade artiole required for the native consumption. The Arab is distinctly a sugar loving individual, and the question of quality dees not trouble him, the main point is quantity. This being the case, it is scarcely surprising to find that the only manufacturers having a footing here are those turning out the cheapest possible artiole which will pass for oonfeotionery,

In view of the quantity sold, the competition for the native supply is to exceedingly keen that the trade is now praotioally in the hands of three or four British firms. It is no uncommon thing to come aoross a commission agent who has lost his entire confectionery oonnection within a few months, owing to another firm having discovered a manufacturer able to sell a shade cheaper —and only a shade—than his own house.

It is, of oourse, impossible to say whether wa have yet reached rook bottom prices, but the following order, reoently sent home by an agent here, will give some idea cf the conditions ruling in the trade.

The requited shipment was to consist of mixed drops, mints with and without pepper, balls, beans, and galatines, and the price 23/- to 25/- the owt, tree English port, payable cash 30 days after rece pt of goods with 2 1/3 % discount As regards the packing, some cf the oases ware to oontain 22 tins of 4 1/2 lbs net, and others of 5 1/2 lbs. The oasks were to hold 86 bottles each weighing 3 1/2 lbs. It is perhaps only fair to add that the manufacturer refused the order on the grounds that his lowest prioe was 27/- per owt. The agent, however, stated that the business could be done at even less than 23/- per owt but, unfortunately, he did not represent the right maker.

The principal kb ds of oheap oonfeotionery sold on this market consist of A.B.C. lozenges, assorted boilings, and mixed drops. After these oome mixed midget beans, fruit pastilles, lemon slice0, tangerine oranges, white garibaldis, ching ch9n*s, and pyramids. An indication of price may be obtained from the figures given in the proceeding paragraph, though we may say that at the present moment, owing to the drop in sugar, the firm which does perhaps the largest turnover in sweets here is, we understand, able to buy at about 21/- per cwt. f.o.b. To this figure must be added say 10 % for freight, and another 10 % for Customs dees and clearing chargee.
A very low class, but exceedingly cheap, sweet kuown as "halawah" comes from Constantinople. It is sent in blooks either loose in barrels or in tins, and has a large sale amongst the Arabs.
There are sundry small coi fectionery factories iD Egypt, the goods turned out being entirely for native consumption.

Taking the second division of the trade viz: the dearer qualities for European consumption, we fiod that the main source of supply is Franoe, her principal speciality being "dragees" i.e. chocolates containing almonds, li queurs, pastes, nuts, etc. The wholesale lates containing cream with different flavour inga. The ohocolates, which are moulded into almost eveiy conceivaVe shape, are wrapped in coloured papers. The cost of producing an article of this deecript;on is naturally high, and it is, therefore, scarcely surprising to find that from 2 frs. 50 cent. (2/-) to 3 fre. 80 cent. (3/-) the kilo c.i.f. Alexandria is the wholesale selling price for the.cheapest qnali!j\

The lowest in the scale of countries competing for the European trade here is Austria, which, in a s:milar manner to Italy, copies Switzerland in the class of confectione*y manu- tactnred. Although outwardly the gcods are in many instances identical with the 8wiss productions, the quality is distinctly inferior and the prices as much as 50 % lower.

In conclusion, we would suggest that home firms, who are Dot already interested here, should turn their attention to the question of supplying this market with the higher grade confectionery e.g. crystallized fruits, dragees, peels, etc. At 21/- par owt. f.o.b. there cannot be very large profits for the manofacturer even taking into account the low quality of the article produced. Ou the other hand, the more expensive sweets certainly offer greater scope in this respect.

It has been said to us by more than one commission agent that England oannot compete with Switzarl^itd as regards quality, leaving prices altoseperofit of the calculation. How far this is true we xSannot say, but the fact remains that the quantity of first class oonfeotionery imported trom England is very small.
(Bulletin of the British Chamber qf Commerce.)

div.head: OLD EGYPTIAN GLASSWARE
div.p: In ancient Egypt the blowing of glass and the contriving of glass vessels were in vogue quite 2,000 y»ars before the Christian era. Mr. Percy Cook Bi°hop, in the coarse of an article on "Glass, Ancient and Modem/' in the "Colleotior's Magazine," points ont that one of the tombs at Sakkara bears a representation of glafs-blowing considered to be the earliest known record of an art whioh, even at that riy date, might have been quite an old- established institution among the dwellers by the Nile. The ancient Egyptian glasswork was usually opaque, and more or less brightly coloured. The vases and other vessels were generally small. Glass beads of various oolours were made, and one of these, still surviving, is reputed to bear the name of Queen Hatason, which, if true, would date this very anoient bead back to about 1440 B.o. In the British Mneeum are many examples cf early Egyptian glass or e of the most notable pieces being the Nineveh goblet, reputed to have left the hands Of Feme glass-worker of ancient Egypt in or about the year 700 B.c. From the Phoenicians and Egyptians the Fecrets of glass-making spread to, and were handed on by, the Greeks, Etruscans, and Sicilians

div.head: CAPTAINS ON MANY SEAS
div.p: Capt. L. T. Carter, 123 10th Ave., Pensacola, _
Fla., writes: ^
"A Hick sailor Is pretty helpless man. I have found that J'oruna will do more to restore one than any other medicine I know, and I have carried a couplo of bottles on board for many seasons.

"Seven years ago Peruna cured me of bronchial trouble in a few weeks and gave me such new life and nerve force that I certainly believe in telling you of it. Olve me my compass and Peruna and I will steer dear of wrecks of all kinds and land In port safe and well with vessel and mcnA'-L. T. Carter.
Capt. E. A. Watson, M. E., 48 Elizabeth street, Ottawa, Ont., writes:
"Peruna has my heartiest endorsement. If there is any place that you are helpless when ill, it is on board a steamer, at sea, miles away from any assistance.
"Sometimes two or three of my men would be siok at one time and serionsly cripple the foroe, but since we have learned of the value of Peruna, by taking a few doses they recuperate very quickly.
"We use it for colds, lung trouble and kidney diseases, and have also found It very fine for la grippe.
"Peruna is always one of the most important supplies of my steamer."—E.A. Watson.
With a bottle of Peruna on board sailors have a remedy on which they can rely.
Commodore U. S. Navy.
Commodore Somerville Nicholson, of the United States Navy, in a letter from 1837 R street, N. W., Washington, D. says:
"/ unhesitatingly recommend Pe» runa to all persons suffering from ca» tarrh.S. Nicholson.

div.head: OUR LONDON LETTER
div.p: London, Febrnary 2. all praotioal purposes the General has come to an end and Sir Henry Campbell Bannennann will meet the new Parliament with by far the largest majority known since the first Reform Bill. featare of the election victories to the Premier most be the enthnsiapm with which his triumph is received abroad. The French, being merely oonoerned in an entente with ns, have indeed made few comments, save on the appointment of the Foreign Minister; but elsewhere there has been general jnbilation. There have been signs of exuberant joy in Germany and Austria, and other States have shown they do not intend to be unheard A telegram of congratulation was sent from the Belgian Liberals to Sir H. Campbell-Banner- man io which he has replied suitably ; and Rnssia has been able to spare some time from her own internal troubles to rejoice at the vitality of the "Kobdenovskie idea" in the country of its origin. A few years ago, we may remember, England was somewhat of an iihmael abroad ; and we must surely all be glad to possess a man whose words, uninspired at times as they may have seemed to oar blind selves, can work a change of feeling BO general throughout the Continent, Critios may object that it would be more satisfactory still if congratulations were equally forthcoming from the colonies, but as in every celebration some small points are overlooked, so in the present case Imperial opinion can well be forgotten in International. It is interesting to observe the unanimous way in which it is proved by our good friends abroad that, although Protection is the only possible policy for them, yet Free Trade is necessary for England. So, we may add, it ie—if their export trade is to flourish at our expense. It may have no importance, but it is ourious that France, whose trade with us is praotically independent of tariffs, has given far less attention to our Fiscal Reform polioy than other countries, whose foreign commerce has been built up on our free imports. It is from the latter that we receive congratulations to-day.

Almost every day brings additional evidence that the Eoglish community throughout South Africa, but more particularly the Transvaal section, believes that the Radical Government at home will shortly play into the hands of the Dopper Boers. 'These irreconcilable) themselves are whispering that their turn fi»r reprisals on the Britishers has arrived, and Het Volk, with unotuoos sanctimoniousness, quietly but firmly inculcates the pagan dootrine of "v® victis." 'There is nothing surprising in this sudden revival of dh'oyalty; Radicalism having adop ed the Majuba attitude to pacify the inner workings of the Nonconformist Conscience, the Dopper* are sufficiently logical to give completeness to the pose.

The gigantio rnsjority obtained \y Sir Henry Campfcel'-Bannerman may or may not turn out to be unmanageable politically, but it is oer* taiu that, physically, it wi 1 be the cause of not a little embarrassment to itself. Supposing the present proportion 8 of parties towards one another are maintained until the eud of the election, it is exceedingly difficult to see where the majority will stow itself. The Radicals and the par ies at present in alliance with them will more than fill the whole Chamber, which was never designed to suit such a state of things as weshall see when Parliament opens.

E en though thi Irish Nationalists remain, arcording to their custom, on the left of the Speaker it will be physically impossible to accommodate the Ministerialists and the Labour members on his right. On great nights they must either take possession of the Peers Gallery, or overflow into the quarters sacred to the Opposition. Either alternative almost equully objectionable. The first would lead not ouly to frictiou with the Peers, but to serious breaches of order, for one may be tolerably certain that a mem her relegated to the gallery through want of room in the House itself, will not consent to be deprived also of his right to cheer or interrupt speeches which stir his feelings. The second alternative—that which I am afraid will be adopted in practice—is even more ohjeotionable. It was the tension caused by the overflow of the one party into the peats usually appropriated to the other which led to that conflict which is the most regrettable incident in all the long history of the Hou^e of Commons. It is not likely that feeling will run less high in this Parliament than it did then, and with the extraordinary d'fhculty of finding room for the Radicals on their own Hide of the House, the greatest tact And owe will have to be exercised to avoid Another and perhaps a worse explosion.

An old complaint against the House of Con mons is that it contains too many barristers ar d too few men of business. There was Always someth brewers and distillers (10), bankers,stock brokers, and & whole miscellaneous company are quite entitled to rank under the same heading. Altogether, business iB well represented in the new House. It remains to be proved that it is a business House.

There is a quite remarkable consensus of opinion among those personally acquainted with Uganda that the East Africa Protectorate will some day become one of the most prosperous provinces of the British Empire. Sir Charles Eliot, than whom there is no higher authority on the subject, coincides with Sir Harry Johnstone ard Sir George Goldie in looking forward to its industrial and economic development with the utmost confidence. 8ome difficulties have yet to be surmounted, it is true, the financial being the most prominent. But the revenue steadily grows with out any enhancement of taxation, vlrle wherever the railway penetrates, productiveness inoreses. The soil is so rich and the olimatio conditions are so suitable for almost all kinds of plant life that no limits can be set to the future expansion of cultivation. There are still large areas of very fertile land which only need European skill and enterprise, backed by capital, to yield good profits, and among them aro soma suitable in every respect for white colonisation. The supply of native labonr is also adequate, the Waganda being immeaaarbly more steadfast as workers than the Kaffirs down Sooth.

It is a pity that more of the surplus labour aud capital of Great Britain does not risk the venture of exploiting the natural resources of the East Africa Protectorate, especially iu the beautiful highlands, with their invigorating climate.

To Lord Roberts and the campaign of education with regard to our military needs wh;ch ho is oonducting the nation may owe a deeper debt than it yet contemplates. If his last remarks at Liverpool seem sweeping and large, it is impossible to assert that his ideas are extravagant Commenting on the neoessi'y of being able to reinforce sea power with our land forces — "the fruits of Trafalgar," paid Loid Roberts, ' were not reaped till Waterloo" he suggested a million msn as the standard which we ought to attain. Of these, 500,000 would be for the defence of India, aud the other half for the purposes of any possible campaign in Europe and the defeuoe of these bores. How that army is to be got and maintained Lord Roberts shows, as he has shown before, And he reverts to that alternative to oinscription, a modified form and measure c f compulsory military training in sohools aud boys' brigades, etc,, which he has always advocated, and which I have always supposed. All that Lord Roberts said should be taken deeply to heart by the nation as a whole, for it is well worthy of close attention, and delays may be daugerons. Speaking of war he said, *T devoutly hope it never may come, but I can say with oonfidenoe that it will come inevitably if you are not prepare!" That is SO true as to be alarming.

The official report of our Consul-General at Hambarg makes it clear that while England still retains the chief balk of India's external oommerce, Germany has been socoessfnlly nibbling at the rioh cake. That wonld, no doobt, be yet more apparent had not Lord Carzon rescued the great sugar industry from the insatiable Teutonic maw. With fine courage, the ex-Viceroy opposed tar ff reform to the subsidy system, and wheo his first effort to stem the tide in that way did not sneoeed as completely as he desired, he followed it by a second of more strenuous character. The outcome is that au industry providing good employment for tens of thousands of Indian workpeople has been ke^t going, without even fractional loss to any one except the Continental producers and exporters of beet sugar. Some of those too enterprising firms have gone down ; others can barely keep their heads above water ; in fine, the Corzon remedy for unfair competition in British market* has, iu this particular instanoe, proved absolutely effective. But the Teuton is not easily choked off when once he has decided to attempt the oapture of important trade. At any cost, he continues the campaign, as witness his repeated purchases of British steamship fleets en gaged in Southern Asiatic trade. It appears to be much the same in the case of India, with the exception of sugar ; Sir William Ward speo'fioally asserts that during the last

In every three or four families there is one il o rit'mate child, more than one in the particularly marine oounties of Elgin, Banff, Aberdeen, and Wigtownshire, as if the neighbourhood of the sea had some effect in this direction, though this theory is contradicted by the faot that the Shetland Isles are particularly free from this stain. Everywhere, however, matters have been steadily improving from year to year for forty years and more.

One of the most startling features in the report is this, that Scotsmen are becoming year by year more subject to oanoer. It appears, however, that different methods of registration are partly respomible for this result, but there ?9 sennthing in it, as is proved by the faot that the years of a man's life when he is peculiarly liable to oanoer, fifty-five to seventy-five, show an increased death rate in contrast with a decrease for all the other years of his life.

Although the net tonnage entering and leaving the Port of London last year showed small increase compared with 1904, we see little in this gain to jastify the optimistio complacency of the Thames Conservators at their last meeting. They make to aooount of the greater briskness of shipping business almost all over the kingdom in 1905, oonse* qnent on the recovery in trade, both home and foreign. When that undeniable improvement is reckoned in, there does not seem mnoh cause for glowing satisfaction in the expansion of 25,689,400 tonnage by saoh a very limited amount as less than 200,000 tons. In the ciroumstanoes, the growth of business at the premier port of the United Kingdom ought to have been considerably larger than that, and the Conservators might have mnoh more reasonably deplored such a stagnant state of things than lauded it as a proof of enhanced prosperity. I do not affirm that shipping bnsiness generally is leaving London, although many experts hold that view. Owing to the prodigious population olose at hand, there must always be a big ooasting trade, carried on by small craft to save the heavy railway rates. Being of shallow draft, these vessels make light of navigation difficulties up river. But the case is wholly different with the great ooean steamers, and I suspect that Liverpool would oome out ahead of London if the coast traffic were eliminated by both.

Not the least significant of the many signs that China is throwing off the sloth of centuries, i» the report that the Chinese women are agitating to remove some of the;r disabilities. The position of the women in the ordinary Chinese household has long been a subject for wooder to European minds, and it is & tremendous step in the direction cf reform that anything is being done to alter that position. Among other things, it is stated that the wife of the ex-Ambassador at Washington is undergoing an operation for the purpose of restoring her feet to their normal shape. Chinese ladies of rank have now almost entirely left off having their children's feet bandaged, aud the effect of this :>n the nation as a whole oannot very well be over-estimated.

It may be that a oritioal hint from a woman's journal may sink deeper into the mind of the average woman than any kind of suggestion from mere men, whose comment m;ght simply besn ffed at, which fate reduce the educational value of comment to precisely nothing at all. The "Gentlewoman" says, briefly, that the Englishwoman, when without any other national strain in her blood, is apt to be uninteresting, and to place man upon a pedestal upon which he finds it hard to keep his footing. "She gives the impression of one who does not think sufficiently for herself." That is the kernel of the "Gentlewoman's" indictment, and it is worth re fleotion and consideration. If an Bng'ish- woman expresses a vivid interest in, say, Browning's poetry, you may confidently sesrch among the men kind of her intimate cirole for a real lover of Browning. If he drops out. Browning drops out of the li«t of our Englishwoman's vivid appreciations In Amerioan women we have strains of various nationalities blended in a nimble, stirring atmosphere of strenuous endeavour an'1 liberal freedom. The resalt, personified, is a woman who proves a veritable magnet in English.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Captain W. J. St J. Harvey, 1st Battalion Black Watch, Fort George, has been selected for servioe with the Egyptian Army. Captain Harvey, who has served in the Royal Highlanders for over fourteen years, reached his present rank in November, 1900. He was with the Black Watch in the advance to Kimberley, and was badly wounded at Magersfontein.

The S S. Dunera, which sails from Southampton on the 10th Febrnary, brings on* troops for the Mediterranean garrisons and Egypt. The latter inoludes 50 non-commissioned officers and men 1st Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, Dnblin, under Lieutenant A. E. F. Harris ; 26 non-commissioned officers and men 1st Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, Belfast, under Captain D. Mathers, reoently transferred to the lnniskillings from the Royal Soots, and Second Lieutenant S. B. Duffin, just appointed to the regiment from the 5th Battalion Royal Irish R flee; and 71 non-oommisaioned officers and men 2nd Battalion Royal Dnblin Fusiliers, Buttevant.

The vacant majority in the 91st (Empress of India's) Lanoers, Hounslow, has been filled by the promotion to substantive rank of Captain and Brevet-Major R Napier Smyth. D.8.0 Major Smyth was with the 21st in the Sudan Campaign of 1890, including their historio oharge at Omdurman (mentioned in despatches, medal and Khedive's medal with o*asp), and he was attached to the 13th Hus-ars in the South African war, including the fighting into Ladysmith, the actions of Colenso, Spion Kop, Val Krantz, and Pieter's Hill (mentioned three times in despatches, brevet majority, D.S.O., medal with two olasps).

The Army Coanoil has notified that the decision to discharge to pension non-commissioned officers of the Royal Garrison Artillery who, on the 1st of Janaary last were over 40 years of age, and has completed over 25 years' service was temporary expedient only and that it is not intended that non commissioned officers who reach the age and servioe mentioned subsequent to the 1st of January, 1906, shall he discharged to pension.

Strict regulations in future are to be enforoed to prevent sailors of the Fleet from smoggliug tobacco ashore. The number of men appie hended for taking large quantities of tobeooo ashore is very mach on the increase, and seamen are now to be restricted to one ounoe of duty free tobacco each lending day. Naval, as well as Custom1, pnoishment will in future follow disobedience of this order.

It is understood that when the battleship Dreadnought is laauohed the particulars of her displacement, armament, construction, and so forth, which are generally officially issued at launches, will not be giveo.

A further disadvantage is the fluctuating strength of companies on change of station consequent on the change of armament to he manned, the strength either having to be increased or decreased. To obviate all these disadvantages the companies will be localised both at home and abroad. The establishment of eaoh station will he maintained by drafts from home depots, or by the individual relief of > ffioers and men, as in the Royal Engineers.

Mr. Arnold Foster's succesor is setting to work as the new broom ; hut there is to be no more clean sweeping. So far as may he seen from the *et eral p'an or his administration published iu "The Standard," he is inclined to act with that oaution and common sense which were expeot- ed of him. A redaction in the fortress artillery, Arhich should effeot some economy, while increasing efficiency, is all to the good as far as it goesy and Mr. Haldane's treatment of the Volunteer.

div.head: Societe Anonyme des Eaux du Caire
div.p: II est port3 à la oonnaissanoe da public qae le Conseil d'Ad ministration de la Sooidtd a dd- oidd de r^iuire de 22 % le prix de l'eau foarnie aux Bornes-fontaines pobliques. En consequence, a partir da ler Janvier 1906 on pourra obtaair l'eaa aux dites tontai nes à raison de P.T. 3 (trois piastres tarif) le metre onbe an lien de P.T. 3,857 payees jus qu'ioi. Cette reduction de prix ayant ete deoidee par la Societe dans le seal bat d'en faire profiter les habitants de la Ville, le public est prie de veiller h ce que la dite redaction lai soit faite par le3 sakas qui lai foarnissent l'eaa, atin de ne pas laisser cas deraiers profiter da rabais qui n'a ete oonsenti qu'en favour da publio. La vente d'e a detail aux Bornes-fontai nes, s'etablit done comma suit : Le tonnean de 660 kilos de jange 20 millimes La gaerbe de 66 „ „ 2 „ L'estagnon de 22 „ „ 3/4 , et pour toute quantite depassant la jauge oi dessus, chaque 4 kilos seront oomptes à 1/8 de millikmes. Le Caire, le 19 Decembre 1905. Le Directeur 26974-30A-18 ASTLEYP. FRIEND.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: La Municipality met en adjudication la vente des immondioes provenaat da balaysge ainsi que da fumier provenaut des ecuries de Ramleh.

Le oahier des charges est depose au Bureau de Nettoiementoh il peuttre consulte par les interesses tons les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours feries exceptes.
Les offres devront 8tre adressees sous pli oaohete à Monsieur TAdministrateur de la Mu nidpalite avant le 20 Fevrier 1906.
Elies pourront egalement 6tre deposeos en seanoe de la Delegation le mkme jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour fachat des immondioes et fumier de Ramleh."

' Le cautionnement ou le recu d'une banque, d'aprks les conditions da oaiiier des charges, devra £tre remis separement au Servioe de la Comptabilite Generale avant l'oaverture des offres et an plus tard le 20 Fevrier à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions oi-dess as sera eoartke.

div.p: CAIRO-ALEXANDRIA TELEPHONE.--Rates as follows P.T. 5 for each 3 minutes, or fraction of 3 minutes; P.T. 10 for over 3 up to 8 minutes communication.

PUBLIC CALL-OFFICES : Cairo, Central Office, Opera Square, and New Bar; Helouan, Central Office, Maison Purvis ; Alexandria, St Mark's Buildings, Egyptian Bar, I. Castelli & Co.; Ramleh, Central Office. San Stefano Casino 30.4.906
